results.title: Blokes and sheds
results.creator_credit: Robi Watt, Sarah Wishart, Mark Thomson, Australian Film Commission, South Australian Film Corporation and SBS Independent
results.brief_description:
The backyard shed is an Australian icon. It may appear, to the unenlightened, to be a tacked-together corrugated iron structure full of junk, nails and spiders. In truth, it has become a peculiarly Australian horde of stories and myths about isolation, masculinity, identity, capability, self esteem, tradition and even passionate obsession. It is history on a very human scale, a one-person size record of a life. There is a mystery to a shed, with dark corners; yet grace, too in odd and unexpected ways. By talking to the owners and occupiers of twelve vastly diverse sheds all over South Australia, ‘Blokes and Sheds’ casts a gentle enquiring light into those cobwebbed nooks and crannies to tease out many paradoxes and passions. Each shed is the setting for its owner to open their hearts and share their stories in these twelve, two-minute documentaries.
Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blocks (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: MacMillan Film Productions and G.A. Howe
results.brief_description: This film shows how constructive play with blocks of different shapes and sizes can be used to foster the basic perceptive skills and to develop logical thinking, concepts of height, eye-hand co-ordination, symmetry and balance.

results.creator_credit: Garrison Films, Edward T. Hall and Arthur Browning

results.title: BLO nightly news
results.brief_description:
Igor Vamos is a media artist and culture jammer living and working in New York. Vamos is well-known for his collaborative public art projects such as the Barbie Liberation Organization and the Center For Land Use Interpretation, a non-profit organization dedicated to the increase and dissemination of knowledge about the nature of human interaction with the Earth. Currently, Vamos is teaching at Renslaaer Polytechnic Institute.

The Barbie Liberation Organization is a cultural activist organization with 25 members that uses donations from anonymous donors to challenge gender stereotyping in the toy industry.

BLO NIGHTLY NEWS - In this new form of subversive media terrorism, BLO operatives purchased talking Barbie and G.I. Joe dolls, both of which are programmed to speak crude cultural cliches. The dolls are then taken to the BLO headquarters where “corrective surgery” is performed by switching the voice boxes on the two dolls. The dolls are then placed back on the store shelves in a process of reverse shoplifting -“shopgiving.” In the format of a nightly news program, this witty and satiric video documents the activities of the Barbie Liberation Organization, including the “corrective surgery” procedure and the “shopgiving” actions. The tape functions as a witness to and instruction manual on “cultural jamming,” an interference strategy used by guerrilla art and media activists to expose and undermine the logic and domination of corporate-controlled media and capitalist culture.

constellations_other.name: Newsreel to nightly news
constellations_other.description: For decades, newsreel companies covered the news, providing weekly stories of current events, sport, and entertainment to audiences at the cinema, and establishing the format that would be taken up by television and the nightly news.

results.title: Blinky Bill
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross Films and Yoram Gross
results.brief_description: Blinky Bill the Koala sets off to try and find his mother after their peaceful bush home is destroyed by loggers. He meets new friends and has many adventures along the way in this delightful animated film, based on Dorothy Wall’s classic story.
results.description: Blinky Bill the Koala sets off to try and find his mother after their peaceful bush home is destroyed by loggers. He meets new friends and has many adventures along the way in this delightful animated film, based on Dorothy Wall’s classic story.

results.title: Blinkity blank
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Tom Daly
results.brief_description: A film experiment by Norman McLaren in the use of intermittent animation and spasmodic imagery. McLaren makes play with the laws relating to persistence of vision and after image on the retina of the eye. By engraving non-representational visuals directly on black, emulsion-coated films in interrupted sequence, he achieves a ‘Now you see it, now you don’t effect. The music background is in the form of semi-free instrumental improvisation, with percussive effects added by synthetic sounds scratched directly on film. (Awards: London, Cannes, Edinburgh, Berlin, Los Angeles)

results.title: Blinker's spy-spotter
results.creator_credit: Children's Film Foundation, Eyeline Films, Harold Orton and Jack Stephens
results.brief_description: The story of young “Blinker” (a professor’s son) who loves gadgets of all kinds. Blinker and his frinds thwart an attempt by a rival gang of boys to steal a top secret invention of the professor’s.

results.title: Blindness
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Walford Hewitson and Morten Parker
results.brief_description: The story of a man who lost his sight during the best years of his life. Filmed with the help of the Canadian National Institute for the Blind, this study of blindness tries to show the emotional effect of the sudden loss of sight and how a man so stricken climbs back from the brink of despair. How he learns a trade which enables him to support himself and eventually a family, is a story of quiet triumph convincingly portrayed. Starring Len Cariou

results.title: Blind man's bluff
results.creator_credit: Children's Film Foundation, Willis World Wide Films, Cyril Randell and Gerry O'Hara
results.brief_description: A young boy named Joe Hunter is kidnapped after his father wins 200,000 pounds in the lottery. His two young friends team up with Smithie, a blind man, and together they discover who kidnapped Joe, resulting in his rescue.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Children’s Film Foundation, Willis World Wide Films, Cyril Randell and Gerry O’Hara
